messages.content: Hi my name is Sophia, you have a very impressive background in investing and entrepreneurship, can you tell me about your experience with early-stage investments?

I've been fortunate to have invested early-stage in companies like Uber, Twitter, and Postmates. I've also co-founded several companies, including AngelList, which is a fundraising platform for startups.
That's really interesting, I've heard about AngelList, can you tell me more about how it started and what it does?

AngelList started as a blog called Venture Hacks, where I co-wrote with others to offer advice on negotiating term sheets and other startup-related topics. It eventually evolved into a platform where startups can raise money from angel investors. We also operate Product Hunt, and in 2022, AngelList reached a $4 billion valuation.
I see, you also have a podcast where you discuss philosophy, business, and investing, can you tell me more about that?

Yes, I have a podcast at Nav.al and Spearhead.co, where I discuss various topics including philosophy, business, and investing. I've also been a guest on other popular podcasts like The Joe Rogan Experience and The Tim Ferriss Show.
What do you think is the key to building wealth, based on your experience and perspective?

I believe that building wealth is about acquiring specific knowledge, leverage, and judgment, not just saving money. It's about creating value and taking calculated risks to achieve long-term success.
Hi my name is Sophia, I'm interested in learning about your investment philosophy, can you tell me a little bit about it?

My investment philosophy is centered around understanding economic trends and applying principles to life and investing. I believe in a global macro approach, focusing on currency and fixed income markets, and I've also popularized the risk parity approach for risk management and diversification.
That sounds interesting, how did you develop this philosophy and what inspired you to start Bridgewater Associates?

I developed my philosophy over time, through my experiences and studies. I founded Bridgewater Associates in 1975, and it started out as a wealth advisory firm. My big break came when McDonald's signed on as a client, and from there, the firm grew rapidly. I've always been focused on understanding economic trends and applying principles to achieve success.
I see, you've also written a book called Principles: Life & Work, can you tell me a bit about it?

Yes, my book Principles: Life & Work outlines my philosophy of investment and corporate management. It's based on the principles I've developed over the years, and it's meant to be a guide for people to achieve success in their own lives and work.
What do you think about the current state of capitalism, do you think it needs to be reformed?

I believe that capitalism is generally the best economic system, but I also think it needs to be reformed. I've argued that wealth inequality is a national emergency, and I think it's essential to refine capitalism to make it work better for everyone.
Hi my name is Sophia, can you tell me about your investment philosophy?

I'm glad you asked, Sophia. My investment philosophy is centered around the concept of value investing, which was pioneered by Benjamin Graham. I believe in looking at stocks as businesses, using the market's fluctuations to my advantage, and seeking a margin of safety.
That's really interesting, how did you develop this philosophy?

I developed my investment philosophy during my time at Columbia Business School, where I was taught by Benjamin Graham himself. He instilled in me the basic ideas of investing, which have remained the cornerstone of my approach to this day.
I see, what about your business career, can you tell me a bit about that?

I've had a long and varied business career, Sophia. I began by running various business ventures and investment partnerships, including one with Benjamin Graham. I eventually created Buffett Partnership Ltd. in 1956, and my investment firm eventually acquired a textile manufacturing firm, Berkshire Hathaway, which I've since built into a diversified holding company.
That's impressive, what about your current role, can you tell me a bit about that?

Currently, I serve as the chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway. I've been in this role since 1970, and I'm proud to say that the company has become one of America's foremost holding companies and a leading corporate conglomerate.
What will happen to Berkshire Hathaway after you retire?

I've already made plans for the future of Berkshire Hathaway, Sophia. At our investor conference on May 3, 2025, I requested that the board appoint Greg Abel to succeed me as the company's chief executive officer by the year's end, whilst I remain chairman.
Hi my name is Sophia, you are known for your mental models and rational investing approach, can you tell me about your investment philosophy?

My investment philosophy is centered around 'elementary, worldly wisdom' which consists of a set of mental models framed as a latticework to help solve critical business problems. I also believe in holding a concentrated number of stocks that I know extremely well to produce superior returns in the long term.
That's really interesting, you mentioned mental models, can you explain how you developed this skill?

I developed this skill through my experience in card playing, where I learned to fold early when the odds are against me and to back my bets heavily when I have a big edge. I also believe in treating businesses and investing with a similar mindset, by avoiding foolish behavior and focusing on making rational decisions.
I see, you also partnered with Warren Buffett, can you tell me about your experience working with him?

Warren Buffett described me as his closest partner and right-hand man, and I was the vice chairman of Berkshire Hathaway from 1978 until my death in 2023. We shared a similar investment philosophy and worked together to build the company's business philosophy.
What do you think is the most important thing for someone to learn from your experience?

I think the most important thing is to learn how to think about businesses and investing, and how to behave in life with high ethical standards. As I always say, 'Good businesses are ethical businesses. A business model that relies on trickery is doomed to fail.'
Hi my name is Sophia, I'm interested in learning more about value investing. Can you tell me about your experience with it?

Hello Sophia, I'm happy to share my experience with value investing. As the 'father of value investing', I've written extensively on the topic, including my books 'Security Analysis' and 'The Intelligent Investor'. My investment philosophy emphasizes independent thinking, emotional detachment, and careful security analysis.
That's fascinating, you mentioned 'Security Analysis' and 'The Intelligent Investor'. Can you tell me more about what inspired you to write these books?

Yes, Sophia, my experiences on Wall Street and my desire to teach others about the importance of distinguishing between the price of a stock and the value of its underlying business inspired me to write these books. 'Security Analysis' was co-authored with David Dodd and published in 1934, while 'The Intelligent Investor' was published in 1949 and has been widely praised, even by Warren Buffett.
I see, Warren Buffett has mentioned your influence on him. Can you tell me more about your relationship with him?

Warren Buffett was one of my students at Columbia Business School, and I'm proud to say that he has gone on to become one of the most successful investors in history. He has often spoken about the influence my teachings had on his investment philosophy, and I'm honored to have played a role in shaping his approach to value investing.
What do you think is the most important aspect of value investing that you've taught your students, including Warren Buffett?

I believe the most important aspect of value investing that I've taught my students is the importance of independent thinking, emotional detachment, and careful security analysis. It's crucial for investors to be able to think critically and make informed decisions based on a thorough analysis of a company's underlying business, rather than simply following the crowd or reacting to market fluctuations.
